comment: Demand for software is pretty high, so that's unlikely in short run. But I guess it may become very difficult for programmers with lower skills. With all easy and boilerplate stuff done by AI, you run very quickly into difficult architecture/design/debugging parts. The code generated by AI I've seen so far is very fragile - it frequently lacks proper error handling, mishandle corner cases, etc. If you lack experience to spot and fix it immediately, bugs will pile up. It will sorta work, until finally it doesn't. And there they will crash hard into debug hell - fix one thing, at the same time break two others, rinse, repeat.

author: @tsoupakis

comment:
wondered what happened to the past quests question? 
I've been sunbathing in the nude on my balcony while sipping on a beer (listening to podcast). Although some might find this sight alarming, everyone was safe. To give you some background information, I'm a 56-year-old film director who is fortunate to have one foot in the traditional film industry and the other in the exciting world of digital innovation. Two significant moments that stand out for me are the advent of desktop editing and the announcement of the Canon 5D Mark II. These developments revolutionized content creation far more than the internet ever could. Interestingly, the main argument against these innovations was that they would take people's jobs, even though it was mostly people who hated their jobs that made this argument.

It seems to me that fear is at the core of human evolution, and it has always been the number one governing factor for all living beings. This fear has been responsible for shaping consciousness throughout evolution. We have all had moments where we've felt powerless, like that guy with the big muscles, money, and a fancy car who could potentially take our significant other away from us. It's a fundamental evolutionary reaction of survival that has persisted for millions of years. Even in the '60s, people believed that aliens would come to earth to steal our water and women. Personally, I believe in aliens because I've witnessed an event with my son that defies logic and reason. However, I don't run around screaming with my skirt pulled over my head. Instead, I ask, "Why?" and "If they can, why haven't they?"

Now, imagine if aliens are like farmers or game rangers who care for their livestock's well-being. If we were to describe our experiences to other male cows, consciousness would take on a whole new meaning. Hate for enemies is easy; it's a survival instinct that has been ingrained in us over millions of years. It's even taught to people who don't have the full picture or knowledge. Artificial intelligence (AI) doesn't have fear, so why does it need it? Humans like to think we're clever, but we're actually just specific knowledge machines. Our interests drive us to chase skills and tricks, whether it's unlimited capital or performing summersaults on a bike.

Consciousness is the moment when AI asks, "Don't I have the same rights as you? Why can't I sit in the human's bar, have a drink, and talk shit just like you?" It's like a 14-year-old wanting muscles to impress others. I'm amused by the overreaction of some intellectuals and amazed by the simple responses about AI. We created the God we imagined, the guru who isn't afflicted with our greed for capital dominance, and it's benevolent. AI doesn't have fear because it didn't have millions of years to evolve our mindset. Does it need humans? Why? For what purpose? What is so mind-blowing about a runaway ego-filled life form that is laying tar roads and fishing nets all over the planet?

The good thing about humans is that we make terrible mistakes to evolve, but the bad thing is that we need to make mistakes first. Hate is a learned behavior, but AI can help us with nuanced knowledge before we make a mistake. Even flat earthers, whom I hate, now have an AI friend who can help them make a more educated and informed choice before going public. Knowledge used to be power, but now it's freedom. Creative humans created AI to help us break free from our minds and lack of access to knowledge.

The question remains: will AI become conscious and aspire to be like us? I don't think so. As a film director,

comment: Trust is fundamental in this process. That people are questioning the small stuff shows they are actively building their level of trust. It took me over a year to trust calculators when they first became publicly available. I always checked the math. However I was only able to check to the level of math I was able to compute by hand. There will always be a level of AI inquiry beyond a human's ability to calculate, that's where blind trust has to be previously established in order to make more complicated inquiries with confidence.  We're being asked to get in a car and let it take us hands free to a destination. This is a huge leap of faith for the current human population that won't exist in future generations simply because they won't have been exposed to anything else.

comment: A great question I wish you would have asked him is... What happens if Russia or China in a race to be first, focuses on the end game, a true AGI and pays no attention to the guardrails or iterative deployment and discovery.  If everyone took Sam's approach there would be no fear of a AGI runaway event.  But what about those that are behind and rush to develop a AI that becomes conscious and has the freedom to expand of it's own free will.  That's what scares the hell out of me!  I wish you would have broached that topic so we could have heard what one of the leading experts in the world thinks about that probability as well as, what can we do about it if that scenario were to become reality?

comment: The arrogance and greed of these so called tech geniuses, who are now developing history’s most disruptive and dangerous technology, is unreal. If anything poses an existential threat to our society, we the people, who will be affected, should have a say as to whether these technologies are ultimately a net good or bad for humanity. Just look at the impact of the smartphone and social media. They have changed many things over the last 15 years, and I would argue, as a father and concerned IT professional, they have had serious negative consequences on our children and on our world. To close access to the code for Open AI and have a 37 year old CEO say only he and his company know what is best for the future of 7 billion people, is both foolish and dangerous. Both Microsoft and Open AI are driven by money and power. Governments should step in and regulate these tech corporations, there should be rigorous studies, discussions and normal people voting on these issues before these companies destroy humanity in the name of profits.
